text: Sudanese protestors gathered in these
streets a few weeks ago the government
sent out its security forces who used
deadly force to crush the protests and
the internet was also shut down and that
leads us to the question because these
people mobilize themselves on social
media is it possible for a revolution to
succeed here today without the Internet
as you see last message last message was
received during the third and we were
able to contact our friends outside the
country actually that used to made us
feel safe the absence of social media is
affecting our our work very much now
that we have to organize for protests
and other activities through phone calls
and SMS this is very slow the number of
people we get to reach is very low
comparing to people with social media
and it's expensive if the social media
wasn't turned off June the 3rd we would
have been able to gather a million
person protests and 100% sure the impact
of the internet shut down goes far
beyond the demonstrators there are some
people here whose livelihoods depend
directly on the Internet
al-rasheed drives a tear howl which is a
local taxi hailing I sold my previous
business to buy this car but since the
internet has been down I'm not even
making twenty percent of what I used to
it's difficult to meet any of my
family's basic needs it's not just
people like Al Rashid who are suffering
Sudan's economy as a whole is estimated
to be losing hundreds of millions of
dollars because of the lack of internet
it's important to remember that when the
protest first kicked off back in
December people took to the streets
because of the economic hardship
the government will try to draw this out
for as long as possible to kill the
momentum among the protest groups but
it's clear the internet shutdown cannot
go on indefinitely and many here say
they will maintain their resolve with or
without the Internet
